Award.AwardTitle: UNS: Dynamics of Microbial Agents in Sewer Systems and Wet Weather Flow

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
1510461
Fahrenfeld

Since wastewater treatment systems are designed to inactivate infectious agents, the Center for Disease Control (CDC) allows urine and fecal matter from patients with infectious diseases to enter sanitary sewers. However, sewer overflows during wet weather flow are a widespread issue in the US. Sewer solids are a major contributor to pollution during urban wet weather flows. Therefore, sewers are not merely a conduit for wastewater, but rather, complex bioreactors: microorganisms can decay, grow, and have their transport attenuated during conveyance. Surprisingly little is known about the biological processes which occur the sewer deposits and their effect on the fate of microbial agents (i.e., pathogens and antibiotic resistant bacteria) and that is the objective of this proposed project.

To perform Quantitative Microbial Risk Assessment for overflow events, optimize sewer maintenance plans, and design wet weather flow treatment, it is necessary to understand the processes affecting the survival of microbial agents (here defined as pathogens and antibiotic resistant bacteria) in sewer solids and biofilms. This is especially true in the case of sewer overflows, but is also important in order to use sewer samples for tracking the incidence of human disease. Sewer surveillance is a useful tool for epidemiology that would benefit from improved understanding of the fate of microbial agents during conveyance in sewer systems. A field survey will be performed to determine the biochemical factors driving the microbial quality of sewer deposits and the relative loading of microbial agents in wastewater and sewer deposits. Next, a controlled simulated sewer experiment will be performed to determine the fate of microbial agents in sewer deposits to provide kinetic data in sewer sediments and biofilm. Finally, a combined sewer overflow (CSO) event will be sampled to characterize the flux of the microbial agents during wet weather flow events. This field study will use the microbial signatures of sewer sediments developed to differentiate between the flux of microbial agents from sewer solids and wastewater. High-throughput, viability-based molecular assays will be applied in this study and allow for sensitive detection of pathogens and the determination of the dynamics of the viable and non-viable antibiotic resistance gene loads. This understanding is essential for determining the risk posed by antibiotic resistant genes in sewer sediments upon release in the environment. Overall, the proposed project will provide critical insight into the fate of microbial agents in sewers and during wet weather flow. The research approach extends biomolecular analytical methods for understanding the fate of microbial agents in sewer deposits. The quantitative data gathered on the environmental factors driving the proliferation of pathogen and antibiotic resistance in sewers will inform quantitative microbial risk assessment, improve models of wet weather pollution events, and aid in the development of mitigation strategies. Of particular interest is the potential application of the knowledge gained here on in-sewer biological processes for improved implementation of sewer surveillance for tracking infectious disease. Sewer epidemiological methods are currently limited by our lack of understanding of critical environmental factors and biochemical processes driving the fate of microbial agents in sewers. Therefore, this work has the potential to transform not only our ability to protect public health during wet weather flow, but also our ability to perform public health surveillance in the sewer matrix. The project targets: (1) recruiting and retaining undergraduate women students in engineering; and, (2) improving scientific literacy. Educational materials and learning modules will be developed and presented biannually in STEM outreach to Girl Scouts (grades 6-12) and at Rutgers Day. A project website will be created to improve public scientific literacy and broaden public knowledge of CSO issues.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual merit:  Sewers collect wastewater that contains disease causing bacteria.  Understanding how bacteria move and survive in these systems is important for (1) understanding the risk posed during sewer overflow events and (2) interpreting wastewater-based epidemiology data.  The use of viability and activity based biomolecular techniques (i.e., DNA sequencing, quantitative PCR) to study antibiotic resistance and the microbiome in sewers was an extension of these techniques to a previously understudied system. 

Sewer overflows during wet weather are a widespread issue in the US, especially in outdated combined sewer systems that collect both wastewater and stormwater in the same pipes.  We performed field sampling during wet weather to understand when and how much antibiotic resistant gene carrying bacteria were released and whether they were associated with the water or the sediments.  Next, laboratory experiments were used to understand the impact of emerging wet weather treatment technologies on antibiotic resistant bacteria in sewer overflow water.  We found that antibiotic resistant gene carrying bacteria were released throughout the storm and more were associated with the sediments released, indicating that removing sediments and the attached bacteria could improve water quality.  Next, in the laboratory we found the ‘green disinfectant’ peracetic acid was effective at breaking cell membranes but not at destroying antibiotic resistance genes, this disinfectant is one being studied for end-of-pipe treatment for combined sewer overflows.  Finally, we found antibiotic resistance gene carrying E. coli killed by peracetic acid disinfection did not regrow in bay water.  This information is useful for designing end-of-pipe treatment systems for wet weather events with sewer overflows.  The viability-based techniques we used for studying the impact of the green disinfectant was also useful for demonstrating that most antibiotic resistant gene were in cells with damaged membranes in treated wastewater, but most were inside of cells downstream in the river. 

To learn about antibiotic resistant bacteria in sewers, sampling was performed across seasons and sewer types (combined and separate) for wastewater and sewer sediments.  The bacteria observed and their antibiotic resistance genes varied by season and between the sample type (wastewater vs. sewer sediments), resulting in potentially different hazards posed by each.  We followed this up by looking for the metabolically active microbes in the sewer, that is, the bacteria making DNA copies.  We found antibiotic resistance genes being copied more often in the sewer sediments than in wastewater.  Looking at the active sewer microbiome also provided insight into which groups containing pathogens or concrete corroding microbes may be growing.  By simulating sewer biofilms, we observed that pipe material did not impact the microbiome or their antibiotic resistance.  Disinfection of the biofilm demonstrated that PVC pipes had more bacteria removed from the biofilm during bleach treatment while concrete had more bacteria remain in the biofilm with damaged membranes.  Overall, these results provide insight in the sewer microbiome as a function of season, pipe material, and sewer type which can be useful as more scientists are interested in performing wastewater-based epidemiology, as highlighted by the COVID-19 pandemic.  Wastewater can provide useful public health information, but the results must be properly interpreted including understanding the potential for bacteria to grow, decay, and/or be trapped in sewer sediments and biofilms: information provided by our work. 

The results of this work were shared in 8 peer reviewed scientific papers, submission of sequencing results to public databases, and several conference presentations. 

Broader impacts:  This project supported one PhD in Civil Engineering and one PhD in Microbiology and Molecular Genetics.  There were also two graduate students visiting scholars and one graduate student participating through a laboratory rotation.  A total of seven undergraduate students worked on the project ranging from short-term assistance with field work, structured year-long or summer research programs such as REU, on up to multi-year laboratory research assistants.  These research experiences included five female engineering students and two students from Puerto Rico.  Two middle school science teachers were hosted on this project through a RET.  Public outreach included hands-on activities at the annual Rutgers Day open house (>620 visitors) and at events for Girl Scouts (>225 girls and their chaperones) to improve public scientific literacy on water quality issues.  A public science lecture describing this work was recorded and is available on YouTube.  A project supplement for the INTERN program allowed one PhD student to work at a major drinking water utility on a pilot treatment project, providing valuable career experience.
